thread.title: Islamic State fighter with links to Manchester 'carries out suicide bombing in Iraq'
thread.title_full: Islamic State fighter with links to Manchester 'carries out suicide bombing in Iraq'

author: Beth Abbit
title: Islamic State fighter with links to Manchester 'carries out suicide bombing in Iraq'
text:
News Islamic State fighter with links to Manchester 'carries out suicide bombing in Iraq' Abu Zakariya is said to have detonated an explosives-filled vehicle in a village to the south of the Iraqi city of Mosul Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
An Islamic State fighter, thought to be from Manchester, has reportedly carried out a suicide bombing in Iraq. 
The terrorist group has named Abu Zakariya al-Britani as the bomber. 
He is believed to have been originally known as Ronald Fiddler, the BBC reports. 
Fiddler, 50, from Manchester, was sent to Guantanamo Bay in 2002. 
The M.E.N previously reported that Fiddler was a former schoolboy in Moss Side. 
Abu Zakariya is said to have detonated an explosives-filled vehicle in a village to the south of the Iraqi city of Mosul. Read More 
Iraqi forces, with the support of Western allies, have been engaged in a major offensive against ISIS in the city for months. ‘HIGH THREAT’: Jamal Al-Harith was held in Guantanamo Bay 
IS claimed on Tuesday that Abu Zakariya was one of two militants involved in the attack on a Shiite army outpost. 
IS said the attack caused a number of casualties. 
There has been no official confirmation of the death, and it is unclear when the attack took place. 
The Britani suffix has been used regularly for militants from the UK. 
A Foreign Office spokeswoman said: “The UK has advised for some time against all travel to Syria, and against all travel to large parts of Iraq. 
“As all UK consular services are suspended in Syria and greatly limited in Iraq, it is extremely difficult to confirm the whereabouts and status of British Nationals in these areas.” 
Around 850 individuals of national security concern have travelled to join the conflict, according to figures published by the Government last year. 
Of those, just under half have returned to the UK and approximately 15 per cent are dead. 
Iraqi forces launched a huge offensive on October 17 to retake the city - Iraq’s second largest. 
They retook control of the eastern side of Mosul last month. 
IS fighters of a variety of nationalities, including Britons, have carried out suicide attacks on many occasions in Iraq and Syria in the past three years. Like us on Facebook
